Americans convinced ourselves that the Iraq debate is behind us. But it's not over among our allies,‚Ä¶
(As a side note, I have to roll my eyes at WH officials who spent years overtly attacking European‚Ä¶
This legacy is why, per , allies are starting to wonder if the problem isn't Trump, it's American voters. And thus permanent.
Iraq is why you see US allies still skeptical, still ready to doubt the alliance and to defy the US. Trump is tapping into all that.
The American debate over Iraq was so politicized that we mistook the damage to our alliances as just a partisan talking point. It wasn't.
Americans are oblivious to this. We wrongly remember European objections to Iraq as purely political, or see them thru our own partisan lens
In the UK, Iraq damaged not just the US alliance but Britain's global role, maybe permanently. Again, Trump is surfacing something deeper.
The Iraq war comes up over and over in my conversations with Euro officials. A lingering doubt about US leadership, which Trump has surfaced
Particularly among European allies and Australia, there is still a sense of distrust and skepticism toward the US over the Iraq invasion.
One crucial piece of context getting lost in assessing Trump's damage to American alliances: the still-healing wounds from GW Bush's tenure.
: Important thread. FWIW, I heard much the same in my convos in Berlin following Merkel's White House visit last March. http‚Ä¶
All to say: Merkel's comment didn't come out of nowhere. Germans have spent months contemplating ‚Äì and preparing for ‚Äì a break with the US.
This is why there's growing European discussion of an extreme option to replace US commitments: a Euro nukes program
Europe's hard line against Russia, which Germany only barely held with US help, seems like the likeliest thing Berlin will have to give up.
So something will have to give. A Europe that has to be self-sufficient, as Merkel said, will also have far narrower ambitions.
No one was sure what Plan B would look like, but they know Germany can't maintain Europe ‚Äì the EU, NATO, keeping out Russia ‚Äì without the US
One told me: The day Trump becomes a threat to German interests, we'll have no choice but to respond. We have to protect ourselves.
One sr German official really stressed this: Our closest ally is not just going away, but may turn its power against us. Think about that.
Their fear wasn't just that Trump would be an unreliable ally, but that his attacks on the EU and NATO would make the US a threat to Europe.
The Germans really fear Europe will fall apart w/o the US. But they saw Trump as a potential threat to their most core national interests.
They were quite open about their plan: appease Trump and proceed normally. But quietly prepare a Plan B in case that fails. We may be there.
/ When I met with German leaders in January, they were already preparing for the possibility of breakup with the US
